summary: This is a memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys in support of her third motion for release on bail. It proposes two additional bail conditions: renunciation of her French and British citizenship, and placement of her and her spouse's assets under the monitoring of a retired federal judge. The document argues these conditions eliminate flight risk and criticizes the strength of the government's case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant seeking release on bail, charged with crimes related to Jeffrey Epstein. She is proposing to renounce her foreign citizenships and have her assets monitored.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Lead attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, filing this memorandum in support of the bail motion.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: William S. Duffey, Jr.
persons.context: Retired federal District Court judge and former U.S. Attorney who has agreed to oversee Maxwell's assets as a condition of bail.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the person Maxwell is allegedly being used as a 'substitute replacement' for in the public narrative.

persons.name: Dominique Strauss-Kahn
persons.context: Former IMF head used as a comparative example in a bail argument; a French citizen granted bail in New York on serious sexual assault charges.

connections.description: Sternheim is the lead defense attorney filing this bail motion on behalf of Maxwell.
Everdell is listed as a defense attorney for Maxwell.
Pagliuca is listed as a defense attorney for Maxwell.
Menninger is listed as a defense attorney for Maxwell.
Judge Duffey has agreed to serve as an asset monitor for Maxwell's finances if bail is granted.
Maxwell is depicted in the media as a 'substitute replacement' for Epstein, indicating their historical association.

events.title: Pretrial Motion Deadline
events.description: Deadline by which Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team filed twelve pretrial motions challenging the government's case.

events.title: Filing of Third Bail Motion Memorandum
events.description: Date the defense memorandum in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's third motion for release on bail was filed with the court.

locations: London (referenced regarding sale of a house)
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell offered to renounce her French and British citizenship as a condition for bail to eliminate concerns she might seek refuge in those countries.
Maxwell proposed having her and her spouse's assets placed in a new account monitored by retired federal judge William S. Duffey, Jr., who would have co-signing authority.
The defense filed twelve pretrial motions by January 25, 2021, arguing they raise substantial legal issues that could lead to dismissal of charges.
The memorandum argues Maxwell is not a flight risk or danger to the community, contrasting her case with that of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, who was granted bail.
The document states Maxwell has lived in the United States for 30 years, is an American citizen, and has strong family ties in the country.
